entry.title: SAP Datasphere Replication Flow Logs: Monitoring & Insights
entry.content:
Introduction

Replication Flow is one of the key artifcate to integrate data from SAP and NON-SAP source system to Datasphere or outside world.

In this blog, we‚Äôll s see how to track Replication Flow execution by accessing key metadata tables and diagnostic views within SAP Datasphere.

 

Step by Step Implementation

 

1) Create a  Database User Group

Begin by creating a global DB user to secure connectivity with underling SAP HANA Database.

Ensure you note down the Host, Port, Username and Password.

Link: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_DATASPHERE/9f804b8efa8043539289f42f372c4862/1097a470be40432e89f91288bdc14378.html 

2) Setup SAP HANA Connection

Establish a connection in your Datasphere space using:

  • Host
  • Port
  • Username
  • Password

This connection enables access to remote tables and metadata views critical for diagnostics.

3) Access Replication Metadata:

Go to Data builder ->  Import Remote table -> select SAP HANA connection.

serach for the space_name$TEC schema (space_name is your space name where Replication flow is created), under that schema import the REPLICATIONFLOW_RUN_DETAILS table.

4) Access Task Metadata:

Get all TASK Related Data from DWC_GLOBAL schema and view TASK_LOCKS_V_EXT

  • Import remote table
  • select SAP HANA connection
  • select DWC_GLOBAL schema
  • select TASK_LOGS_V_EXT view

5) Merge the data from both tables:

Join/Union both the tables and get all the required fields as per the requirement.

Conclusion

By building a model on top of these two tables, you can view all the metadata related to your Replication Flows. This helps you track key details like execution time, status, and any errors. So if something goes wrong, you'll be able to quickly identify and understand the issue.

Thanks

Vikas Parmar

SAP Datasphere  SAP Business Data Cloud

entry.title: The Value of SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) in The Context of Business Steering
entry.content:
This blog post is a joint work of @Nektarios_Vasileiou33 and @BlazZabukovec .

Picture 1: SAP Analytics Cloud demo story example - Dashboard design by Daniel Davis

 

MOTIVATION

In today's fast-paced business world, the ability to effectively steer and lead an organisation is fundamental for achieving strategic goals and maintaining a competitive edge. A key success criterion is the capacity to fully harness and derive value from organisational data. Many companies struggle with data problems, such as fragmented information, outdated systems, and the super important task of preparing data for emerging technologies like AI. Recognising these challenges, we are excited to introduce a blog series dedicated to showcasing the substantial business value of SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) in the context of planning and analytics.

The motivation behind this initiative is to provide a comprehensive exploration of how SAP BDC capabilities as essential instruments, facilitating robust strategic alignment and guiding effective decision-making processes across diverse organisational requirements. We aim to illustrate how SAP BDC, equipped with powerful data management, planning, analytics and innovative AI capabilities, empowers organisations with enhanced business steering agility by providing real-time insights, streamlined data management, and automated decision support ‚Äì going from insights to action, helps mainly leaders guide their businesses with precision.

Our blog series will provide valuable insights for decision-makers seeking to harness SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) to enhance operational efficiency, optimise resource allocation, and achieve long-term objectives. By featuring detailed planning & analytics topics, the series will illustrate the transformative impact of SAP BDC in addressing the operational complexities of today‚Äôs business environment. This first introductory blog post will spotlight the strategic advantages of SAP BDC, particularly in the context of Business Steering, setting the stage for a deeper exploration of its benefits throughout the blog series.

There are several blog posts in the series that will cover advantages of SAP BDC in the context of business steering, so please stay tuned for the upcoming blogs:

  1. The value of SAP BDC in the context of business steering (THIS BLOG POST)

  2. Is AI going to ‚Äúretire‚Äù a dashboard?

  3. Simulations, a game changer in today‚Äôs volatile world

  4. Planning & Analysis in the context of SAP BDC

  5. Move BPC and BW-IP into SAP BDC

  6. Real-time steering with LIVE planning

  7. PaPM use cases

  8. Self ‚Äì service analytics and real time business steering

  9. Business steering powered by AI agents

  10. Leverage data products in the context of planning & forecasting

  11. Introducing AI/ML capabilities by SAP Databricks

 

CHALLENGES

The current global market situation is characterised by heightened volatility and uncertainty, driven by factors such as geopolitical tensions, inflationary pressures and rapid technological advancements. In this dynamic environment businesses face significant challenges like supply chain disruptions, rising and uncontrolled operational costs and the need for digital transformation to remain competitive.

Obviously, there is no one-size-fits-all solution to every challenge, but adopting a data-driven decision-making process provides significant advantages that can help organizations navigate complexities and respond more effectively to market dynamics. By relying on data to drive decisions, businesses can achieve greater accuracy and insight, which helps in identifying trends, understanding customer behaviours, and optimising operations. This approach enables companies to be more agile and responsive to changing conditions.

Every leader today feels the weight of growing complexity. CFOs balancing growth and profitability. CHROs managing talent in an evolving workforce. CIOs modernising IT while keeping innovation alive.

Picture 2: Challenges by CXO persona

But the true challenge lies in how these functions are increasingly interconnected. When one part of the business is disrupted, whether it‚Äôs a supply chain issue or a talent gap, the ripple effects are felt everywhere. To succeed, businesses need more than solutions for individual challenges, businesses need a way to align every function and unlock collective power.

Like Aristotle (apparently) once said: ‚ÄúTHE WHOLE IS GREATER THAN THE SUM OF ITS PARTS‚Äù

Today‚Äôs complexity demands more than incremental fixes and silo apps/solutions. If we want to have benefits from AI and systems of agents collaborating across all functions, we need to have a solid foundation, where we can seamlessly combine applications, data, insights and AI into one ecosystem.

Just picture this example around Financial Planning (incl. forecasting & simulation), where we can develop a comprehensive financial snapshot while automating workflow tasks through agentic AI.

Picture 3: Forecasting & Simulation use case evolution

This is where we bring together all relevant data, like revenues, expenses, also across different scenarios, like actuals, plan & forecast. We also integrate all relevant external data, like different macro-economic KPIs, external market research data., etc. Based on identified key drivers/influencers of our business, we are going to define and perform different planning/forecasting scenarios. In the next step we are going to simulate and analyse impact of external drivers like inflation rate on our performance and identify the areas that will be impacted. Specialised analytics agent can propose potential mitigation strategies, like targeted promotions to drive customer demand, that can be further assessed & analysed. Based on this information we can decide for a certain course of actions that can be triggered by system of agents.

Picture 4: Risk analysis & mitigation strategies delivered by agentic AI

We can say with great confidence that our customers are not working in the area of visualising their data and that‚Äôs why SAP is also not in the business of visualising our customer‚Äôs data (even though we can do this is in a great way), but we are in a business of enabling the ‚ÄúInsights to Action‚Äù framework which is exactly what I have illustrated in the use case around financial planning powered by agentic AI.

Organizations striving to make data-driven decisions and a proper, also AI powered jump from insights to action, encounter several significant challenges. One major obstacle is seamlessly integrating data across various systems to extract valuable business insights. Additionally, ensuring data quality and integrity is crucial to maintaining trust in the decision-making process. Furthermore, building a comprehensive data foundation is essential for supporting the deployment of AI-based applications. Addressing these challenges requires robust data management strategies and innovative solutions to harness the full potential of data for valuable decision-making.

 

SAP's STRATEGY

To tackle these challenges, SAP developed the SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) to provide cloud services that empower organizations in navigating the complexities of data management and business steering process. SAP BDC serves as a unified platform, providing the necessary agility for effective business steering. SAP BDC offers a semantically rich, unified data environment that enhances operational efficiency and strategic decision-making capabilities. By centralising key business data from SAP and non-SAP sources into a unified semantic layer, SAP BDC unlocks insights, advanced analytics, and AI capabilities, empowering businesses to drive intelligent growth and innovation.

Picture 5: SAP Business Suite

SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) is a fully managed Software as a Service (SaaS) solution that unifies and governs all SAP data while seamlessly connecting with third-party data. The solution combines the capabilities of SAP Datasphere, SAP Analytics Cloud, and SAP Business Warehouse, along with managed SAP Databricks. SAP BDC includes curated business-ready data products from SAP line of business applications leveraged by business-ready Intelligent Applications providing line-of-business leaders the context needed to make impactful decisions.

Picture 6: High level overview of SAP BDC services

Key Components of SAP Business Data Cloud:

SAP Datasphere: As the foundational element of SAP Business Data Cloud, SAP Datasphere provides a streamlined environment for data integration, warehousing, and governance. It features flexible integrated data tiering‚Äîcomprising object, disk-based, and in-memory storage‚Äîensuring a cost-effective persistence layer. Additionally, it offers sophisticated tools for analytical data modeling, transformation, and integration, enabling organizations to extract valuable insights and foster business innovation. Users can also utilize the framework to develop their own data products.

SAP Analytics Cloud: This component delivers cutting-edge analytics and planning capabilities while providing real-time insights powered by AI and machine learning. It integrates seamlessly with SAP Datasphere to offer a unified data analysis experience.

SAP Databricks: Through SAP's partnership with Databricks, data science capabilities are significantly enhanced. This collaboration facilitates advanced analytics and data science operations on both SAP and non-SAP data. Key features include ML Flows for machine learning operations, Mosaic AI for model training and serving, and Notebooks equipped with coding assistants and visualizations. The serverless Spark offerings aim to simplify big data processing, while replication-free access to SAP data products and integration with the Unity Catalogue further enrich the experience.

Intelligent Applications and Data Products: SAP Business Data Cloud emphasizes Intelligent Applications and SAP-managed Data Products. These ready-to-use, standardized business data objects and applications are managed by SAP, reducing the effort needed to build and operate analytical and data science applications. They promote data consistency and reusability, serving as modular, reusable assets for analytical models or AI/ML and planning workflows.

Unified Semantic Layer: Central to SAP Business Data Cloud is the unified semantic model, which standardizes data definitions across SAP and non-SAP systems. It offers simplified zero-copy data access via a standardized delta-share interface, supporting cross-domain analytics and AI applications. Additionally, it features a centralized cross-application catalog for data products and Intelligent Applications.

SAP BW: is integrated into SAP BDC, allowing SAP BW objects to be onboarded as data products. The SAP BW data products can be integrated in SAP Databricks to enable advanced analytics and data science use cases.

 

BUSINESS VALUE

SAP BDC delivers significant business value in the context of business steering, particularly within planning and analytics use cases. 

Enhanced Decision-Making: SAP BDC revolutionises decision-making by providing real-time access to integrated data. This SAP Analytics Cloud capability ensures that business leaders receive accurate and immediate insights, empowering them to make informed and strategic decisions. With this enhanced decision-making capacity, organizations can effectively anticipate market trends, adjust their strategies in response to evolving conditions, and maintain a competitive edge in their respective industries.

Comprehensive Data Integration: At the heart of SAP BDC is its ability to seamlessly integrate data from multiple sources, both SAP and non-SAP systems. This integration creates a unified view of the organisation's data landscape, supporting precise planning and predictive forecasting. By breaking down data silos and ensuring a holistic perspective, SAP BDC enables businesses to gain comprehensive insights into their operations and make well-rounded decisions. The data holistic perspective is fundamental for organizations to unleash AI across the entire data ecosystem.

Scalable Analytics and Planning Capabilities: One of the standout features of SAP BDC is its scalable analytics and planning capabilities. It allows businesses to conduct extensive analyses and simulations, uncovering valuable insights that aid in tailoring forecasts to specific scenarios. Whether it's understanding customer behavior or predicting market shifts, SAP Analytics Cloud robust analytics and planning capabilities in combination with SAP Databricks empower organizations to make data-driven predictions with unmatched precision and confidence.

Improved Efficiency and Agility: SAP BDC streamlines data integration and analytics processes, significantly enhancing efficiency and agility within organizations. By automating these crucial processes, leveraging data management features in SAP Datasphere, analytics in SAP Analytics Cloud and AI/ML workflows in SAP Databricks, it cuts down the time and effort needed for data preparation and analysis (replication free access of data and zero-copy). This efficiency allows teams to redirect their focus from operational concerns to strategic steering, driving more meaningful business results in less time.

Facilitated Innovation: Leveraging cutting-edge technologies such as artificial intelligence and machine learning, SAP BDC promotes innovation within organizations. Its cloud-based infrastructure ensures that businesses have access to the latest advancements, encouraging the exploration of new and innovative business models. This focus on facilitated innovation helps companies remain at the forefront of industry trends and continuously evolve their offerings.

Consistency in Data Governance: Ensuring data integrity and consistency is a critical component of SAP BDC's value proposition. The platform offers comprehensive data governance and quality management, providing reliable data integrity across planning and analytics activities. With consistent data definitions and governance, businesses can achieve accurate reporting and foster alignment across various departments, leading to cohesive planning strategies.

Seamless Collaboration: SAP BDC enhances collaboration by centralising data accessibility and sharing. Data Cataloguing, Data Sharing and Collaboration capabilities foster improved teamwork among departments and enables synchronised planning efforts and a guided steering process. With shared insights and aligned goals, teams can work together more effectively, driving unified strategies and achieving common objectives that benefit the entire organisation.

Strategic Resource Allocation: Through its predictive analytics and planning capabilities SAP Analytics Cloud and SAP Databricks, SAP BDC enables organizations to allocate resources more strategically. By delivering actionable insights, businesses can optimize operations, improve resource allocation, and enhance overall performance. This strategic approach ensures that resources are used efficiently to achieve maximum impact, driving profound business success.

Future-Proofing Autonomous Business Steering: By harnessing SAP AI agents within the trusted SAP BDC data foundation, the planning and business steering process is transformed from a static, periodic exercise into a dynamic, proactive function. These AI-driven insights empower companies to swiftly assess the potential impacts of various strategic options and make decisive actions. This approach allows businesses to anticipate market changes and respond efficiently, making strategic adjustments with confidence and precision.

 

CONCLUSION

SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) stands as a vital tool for organisations striving to enhance their decision-making capabilities, align strategic objectives, and navigate the complexities of modern business landscapes. In the era of AI, organizations require scalable and efficient data architectures to manage growing volumes of data and extract actionable insights leveraging advanced analytics, planning and machine learning capabilities. As we embark on this informative blog series, we invite you to stay tuned for our upcoming posts, where we will delve deeper into the AI, Planning & Analytics functionalities associated with SAP BDC and business steering use cases. Gain insights into how this powerful platform can drive your business forward, optimise operations, and help you achieve your strategic goals with confidence. Join us in exploring the transformative potential of SAP BDC and discover how it can be the catalyst for your organisation's growth and success.

 

CALL TO ACTION

To deepen your understanding of SAP Business Data Cloud, we invite you to explore the following links:

SAP Business Data Cloud Help

https://help.sap.com/docs/business-data-cloud?locale=en-US

Introducing SAP Business Data Cloud

https://learning.sap.com/learning-journeys/leveraging-sap-analytics-cloud-functionality-for-enterprise-planning/introducing-sap-business-data-cloud

Positioning SAP Business Data Cloud

https://learning.sap.com/learning-journeys/positioning-sap-business-data-cloud-1

entry.title: SAP Datasphere News in July
entry.content:
SAP Datasphere News in July

Another month with two great new release deliveries ‚ú®
Learn more in my short top features video in July 2025 on YouTube üì∫
In addition, explore the latest updates in our community news blogs.

 

 

My top features in July

 

Data Integration & Connectivity

Secure File Transfer Protocol (SFTP) as Source for Your Replication Flow

After delivering SFTP as a target already in May this year, you can now also use SFTP connections as sources in replication flows to any supported target.

‚û°Ô∏è   More information:

  • Secure File Transfer Protocol (SFTP) as Source for Your Replication Flow
  • Generic SFTP Connections

 

Transport Objects Between File Spaces

You can now export objects from and import objects to file spaces, meaning a space based on the embedded object store with file-based artifacts.

‚û°Ô∏è   More information

 

Task Chains

New Layout Option in Task Chain Toolbar

The options in the task chain editor toolbar have been re-arranged and a new layout option was added. The new layout option allows you to rearrange the visual display of a task chain on the canvas, from top-to-bottom (the default), or left-to-right.

‚û°Ô∏è   More information

 

Connection Type Generic HTTP

With the new connection type, you can connect to external systems and add tasks that are exposed by REST-based APIs to task chains. For this purpose, we have introduced the new API Tasks connection feature, which is supported only for Generic HTTP connections.

‚û°Ô∏è   More information

 

Running API Tasks in a Task Chain

The generic HTTP connection is the prerequisite to provide the ability of running tasks in a task chain that use a REST-based API to access external systems.

‚û°Ô∏è   More information

 

New Notification Task Object in Task Chains

SAP Datasphere now allows users to set up additional email notification within a task chain, in addition to the notification specified for completion of the entire task chain. Users drag the new Notification Task object to any point in the sequence of tasks run in a task chain and then specify the subject and message for this new email notification. These new notifications use the same recipient list as the email notification maintained at the task chain level.

‚û°Ô∏è   More information

 

Self-Service Enhancements

Enable Multi-Availability Zones for SAP HANA Cloud

Use the Enable SAP HANA Multi-Availability Zones option on the Tenant Configuration page to create a synchronous replica of the main system on a system in a different region. The synchronous replica system has a high-availability setup that can take over processing when necessary.

‚û°Ô∏è   More information:

  • Configure the Size of Your SAP Datasphere Tenant
  • Creating and Configuring Your SAP Datasphere Tenant

 

Enabling of SAP HANA for SQL data warehousing on Your SAP Datasphere Tenant

Administrators can now create the mapping between their SAP Datasphere tenant and their SAP Business Technology Platform account to enable SAP HANA for SQL data warehousing themselves, rather than needing to raise a ticket. Both environments for Kyma and Cloud Foundry are supported and the same information as previously required for the ticket with Organization ID and Space ID is required to be able to do the instance mapping.

‚û°Ô∏è   More information

 

 

 

Webinar Series: Architecting Your SAP BDC Journey ‚Äì From Data to Intelligence 

There was a great architecture webinar series about SAP Business Data Cloud and various architecture deep dive topics. Thanks to @Gaurish-Dessai, @PaulKurchina, @helmut_grimm and team.

entry.title: Currency and unit conversion in SAP Datasphere Analytic Model with variable and value help
entry.content:
Currency conversion is the act of changing financial information from one currency into another. This process is especially crucial for global businesses that conduct operations across various countries and handle transactions in multiple currencies.

Unit conversion is also important because it ensures consistency, accuracy, and clarity when working with different measurement systems. Unit conversion enables accurate, effective communication and operations across systems, industries, and borders.

The following steps are carried out for currency / unit conversion in SAP Datasphere:

1. Create currency / unit conversion tables and views

2. Create a task chain and schedule it

3. Determine the semantic type and the associated unit in the fact view

4. Create input parameters with input help

5. Add conversion measure in analytical model

For currency conversion these tables must be available in your SAP S/4 HANA system:

  • TCURV - Exchange rate types
  • TCURW - Exchange rate type text
  • TCURX - Decimal places in currencies
  • TCURN - Quotations
  • TCURR - Exchange rates
  • TCURF - Conversion factors
  • TCURC - Currency codes
  • TCURT - Currency text

For unit conversion these tables must be available in your SAP S/4 HANA system:

  • T006 - Units of Measurement
  • T006D - Dimensions
  • T006A - Assign Internal to Language-Dependent Unit

    1. Create currency / unit conversion tables and views

a) Start the creation of the corresponding tables and views in the correct space in the Data Builder via Create and Currency / Unit Conversion Views

b) Choose source system and check objects. 

c) After clicking on ‚ÄúCreate‚Äù, all objects are created automatically.

2. Create a task chain and schedule it

Create a task chain and include all relevant data flows to upload data into the required tables. To keep the data up to date, it is advisable to schedule the task chain.

3. Determine the semantic type and the associated unit in the fact view

In the fact view, which is located under the analytical model, you must maintain the semantic types of the key figures and the associated units. Conversion in the analytical model can only take place through this step.

4. Create input parameters with input help

If the user is to be provided with a value aid when calling up variables, one or more input parameters must be created in the fact view.

If you only want to provide users with a narrow list with a few units, you can build a view on the unit table and enter it here as value help. You can also set a default value here.

Attention: You may have to set the field length of WAERS to 3 in the view.

5. Add conversion measure in analytical model

a) You can now create conversion measures in the analytical model.

b) Enter business name and technical name for your new measure. Select source measure. SAP Datasphere uses the source key figure to recognize whether a unit or currency conversion needs to be carried out.

c) Select the date to which you want to convert and the appropriate exchange rate type (only for currency translation). Then click on the selection help for Target Currency and select ‚ÄúVariable‚Äù.

Click on "Use existing Source Variable" and choose the correct one.

d) Under ‚ÄúAdvanced‚Äù, select the client that is maintained in the TCURR table and what should happen if an error occurs.

TCURR:

e) Go back to main Analytic Model Properties and check error messages or test the new measure in preview.

Tip:

If the analytical model existed before the input parameters were created in the fact view below, they must be mapped manually to new or existing variables.

 

Conclusion

Currency and unit conversions are foundational components in ensuring data integrity, consistency, and meaningful analysis in multinational environments. SAP Datasphere offers a structured and streamlined approach to managing these conversions by leveraging integrated tables from SAP S/4HANA and guided steps within the Data Builder and analytical model.

By systematically creating conversion views, automating data flows through task chains, assigning semantic types, configuring input parameters, and defining conversion measures, users can implement robust, scalable conversion logic. This ensures that financial and operational data across diverse units and currencies are harmonized and ready for accurate reporting and decision-making.

entry.title: This Is the Way: Rethinking Analytics Orchestration with REST in SAP Datasphere
entry.content:
Introduction

SAP Datasphere Task Chains have recently been enhanced with a new capability: the ability to add a REST API Step, as documented by SAP. This addition significantly expands the integration potential of Task Chains, allowing them to trigger or interact with external systems via REST APIs‚Äîsomething previously not possible within the task chain framework itself.

While SAP Datasphere already offers a Command Line Interface (CLI) for interacting with its environment, I believe that technical automation‚Äîespecially triggering Task Chains‚Äîshould be handled via REST endpoints wherever possible. (Yes, I am aware this is already on the roadmap.)

If you have followed the evolution of SAP Analytics Cloud, you have likely noticed how its REST API capabilities have grown considerably. This trend strongly suggests a broader strategic shift within SAP toward more API-driven architectures.
Beyond the technical implications, this new feature offers a glimpse into how future data and analytics architectures might be designed. The ability to call external REST APIs directly from within a Task Chain is a small yet significant change‚Äîit paves the way for loosely coupled, event-driven, and more modular system landscapes.

In this blog post, I will explore the broader implications of this feature‚Äîlooking at both architectural perspectives and practical use cases‚Äîto illustrate how this seemingly simple addition might shape our thinking on modern data platform design going forward. The different implications and perspectives I will try to sketch out in this blog post.

Integration Perspective

With this new capability, you can invoke a REST service directly within a process step. What could such a REST service do? Here are a few examples:

  1. Microservices and Third-Party Data Sources - Trigger a microservice that extracts data from a third-party system and writes it into SAP Datasphere using the OPEN SQL schema.
  2.  Advanced Analytics on External Buckets - Initiate a predictive analytics process after data has been pushed to an external storage location (e.g., a Google Cloud Storage bucket), leveraging external computation power or models.
  3. Endless Possibilities - from orchestrating workflows to enriching data pipelines with external intelligence.

This simple yet powerful feature drastically lowers the barrier for integrating external systems. Especially in modern, heterogeneous IT landscapes, the ability to seamlessly interact with REST services is crucial. As solutions increasingly span multiple platforms and technologies, having native support for REST APIs within Task Chains enables more modular, scalable, and interoperable architectures.

SAC Seamless Planning Perspective

At present, Seamless Planning in SAP provides only a foundational set of features. However, even with these basic capabilities, it is now possible to trigger a Multi Action in SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC)‚Äîwith some lightweight technical implementation, such as a microservice on SAP BTP to handle user propagation.

What Does This Enable?

It opens the door to scheduling planning-related actions that can be executed automatically‚Äîdaily, during off-peak hours, or at custom intervals‚Äîall orchestrated directly from SAP Datasphere. This marks a significant step toward greater automation and operational efficiency in planning processes.

Looking ahead, the possibility of triggering a Task Chain from within a Multi Action (either via SAP‚Äôs upcoming official Task Chain Trigger feature or through a custom-built solution) would close the loop, enabling bi-directional process orchestration between SAC and Datasphere.

A Vision of Integration - Imagine this scenario:

  • Master data is loaded from an S/4HANA system into Datasphere (where the Master data may be managed in the future) and updated in the planning model.
  • Once this loading process is completed, a Data Action is automatically triggered to generate the necessary planning combinations.
  • Each step is orchestrated across systems‚Äîseamlessly integrating Datasphere and SAC.

This evolving capability points to a promising future, where SAP‚Äôs tools are moving toward more open, event-driven, and tightly connected architectures. It is a strong signal of the direction SAP is heading‚Äîtoward building truly integrated, cross-platform planning and data ecosystems.

Process Orchestration

As outlined in the sections above, these new capabilities significantly enhance our ability to orchestrate analytics processes‚Äîin ways that were not possible just a few weeks ago. The integration of REST API steps and the evolving connectivity between SAP Datasphere and SAC unlocks a new level of flexibility.

What makes this particularly compelling is the ease with which we can now develop lightweight microservices on SAP BTP to support and extend these interactions. Whether it is handling authentication, user propagation, or orchestrating complex logic between systems, BTP provides a robust platform for embedding custom logic into an increasingly modular and responsive analytics architecture.

The On-Premises Thoughts

I have already referred several times to the concept of a ‚Äúsmall microservice on SAP BTP.‚Äù This idea becomes especially relevant when you consider that SAP Datasphere is still often used alongside SAP BW, where orchestration tasks are traditionally handled via Process Chains and ABAP reports.

In many discussions‚Äîwhether with internal teams or external consultants‚Äîthere remains a strong inclination to implement logic directly within the ABAP stack of on-premise systems. This is understandable. It is what I would call the ‚Äúhome-field advantage‚Äù: familiarity, confidence, and reliability in an environment they know well. They‚Äôre certain it will work‚Äîbut the question we must ask is: Will this remain a sustainable approach over the next 5 to 10 years?

The reality is that, SAP‚Äôs Business Data Cloud is on the rise, and the centrality of BW in analytics architectures is gradually diminishing. So why not embrace a more future proof approach?

By building a lightweight REST service on SAP BTP, we gain a flexible, scalable solution that can be triggered both by SAP BW and SAP Datasphere. This doesn‚Äôt just modernize our architecture‚Äîit lays the groundwork for future-proof integration patterns, better modularity, and easier maintenance in a cloud-centric world.

A broader architectural perspective

Another powerful dimension of this development is the ability to interact with a broader range of services available on SAP BTP, such as SAP Event Mesh. For example, you could emit an event to a queue and have that event trigger specific reactions among subscribed services. This pattern‚Äîsimilar to what has long been possible in SAP Data Intelligence using simple Pub/Sub mechanisms‚Äîenables a much cleaner, event-driven architecture that is better aligned with modern cloud-native design principles.

But this blog is not just about the ‚Äúsmall‚Äù new feature of the REST API step. It is about what this feature represents: a clear signal of how the SAP Analytics ecosystem is rapidly evolving toward the Business Data Cloud‚Äîwith SAP Datasphere, SAP Analytics Cloud, and SAP Databricks at its core (leaving SAP BW Private Cloud Edition aside for now).

This shift demands a mindset change for analytics consultants. To remain relevant and deliver robust solutions, we must go beyond our comfort zones and understand how SAP BTP enriches this ecosystem. That includes learning how to build with CAP or UI5, orchestrate processes using SAP Build, and embrace loosely coupled, service-based thinking.

It‚Äôs no longer just about reporting and data modeling‚Äîit's about understanding how to leverage the entire BTP toolset to design smarter, more flexible processes that are fit for the future.

Conclusion

The REST API step in SAP Datasphere Task Chains is much more than a technical enhancement‚Äîit is a strategic inflection point. It pushes SAP architecture toward:

  • Greater openness and interoperability
  • Microservice- and event-driven thinking
  • Tighter orchestration between SAC, Datasphere, and BTP
  • A cleaner transition from legacy on-prem ABAP logic

The future is modular, cloud-native, and integrated‚Äîand this is your chance to start designing for it.

entry.title: SAP Business Data Cloud Series ‚Äì Part 1: Introduction to Data Products
entry.content:
Introduction:

Data products are the foundation of SAP Business Data Cloud, serving as the core building blocks of the platform. Each data product is a curated package of business process data and its associated semantics, metadata, harmonized and replicated from SAP applications like SAP S/4HANA, SAP Ariba, SAP SuccessFactors, SAP Concur, etc. SAP handles the entire replication process, ensuring data is reliable and consistent. For example, a Sales order data product contains mainly 2 entities, Sales order and Sales order item, and all relevant fields like order number, customer, product, quantity, and delivery date. Beyond raw table data (VBAK, VBAP) , metadata plays a critical role‚Äîit adds meaning, context, and relationships between data elements, such as linking a product to its supplier or defining its description in multiple languages.

This blog series explores:

  • What are data products? What are the data packages ?
  • Why do we need data products instead of tables ?
  • What types of data products exist? 
  • Difference between data products?
  • How to extend, create, or manage them?
  • What benefits do data products bring to your data strategy?
  1. SAP Business Data Cloud Series ‚Äì Part 1: Introduction to Data Products.
  2. SAP Business Data Cloud Series ‚Äì Part 2: Extend SAP S/4HANA Managed Data Products.
  3. SAP Business Data Cloud Series ‚Äì Part 3: Customer-Managed Data Products Coming soon....

üîçWhat Are Data Products in SAP Business Data Cloud?

Data products are core building blocks within SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC). They are curated data sets that include both raw business data and rich metadata, harmonized and replicated from SAP source systems. These data products are designed to be easily consumable, reusable, and trusted sources of truth across analytical and business applications. Crucially, Data Products are fully governed and made available via APIs and a Data Product Directory, allowing them to be easily discovered and used across the organization.

Each data product is self-describing, meaning it includes not only the data itself but also metadata such as:

  • Interface definitions for data extraction
  • Delta-load capabilities
  • Technical documentation
  • Semantic and relationship details (e.g., Product ID with descriptions, supplier info, customer info, currency, unit of measure etc.)

üß± Types of Data Products

SAP BDC supports three types of data products, based on ownership and development:

  • SAP-Managed Data Products: Delivered and maintained by SAP. These are standardized and regularly updated as the source application evolves.
  • Derived Data Products: Curated by SAP and built by leveraging existing Data Products.
  • Customer-Managed Data Products: Created by customers to suit their specific data needs.
    • Custom Data Products: Example would be created based on the Z CDS entities or non-SAP data loaded into the SAP Datasphere Object Store.
    • SAP BW Data Product Generator: SAP BW 7.5 or BW/4HANA Private Cloud feature, this pushes data to the SAP Datasphere Object Store. Created local tables can be shared as data products (Via Data sharing Cockpit).
  • Partner-Managed Data Products: Built by SAP partners, often tailored for industry-specific use cases.
  • 3rd Party Data Products: Built and managed by 3rd party partner. Delivered to SAP Datasphere tenants via Data Marketplace. Can be licensed for free or at cost defined by the 3rd party partner.

üîç Key differences between SAP-Managed and Customer-Managed Data Products:

Both types of data products are technically the same, stored in an object store (HDLF), defined using an Open Resource Discover (ORD) JSON files, and published in the data catalog. However let us look at some key differences:

üîç Aspectüü¶ SAP-Managed Data Productsüü© Customer-Managed Data Products
üë®‚Äçüíº Ownership
  • Defined, Owned and Managed by SAP (complete life-cycle)
  • SAP manages data extraction, transformation, load, harmonization.
  • SAP manages metadata, business logic, semantics, associations, schemas and APIs.
  • Owned and Managed by Customer
  • Customer manages metadata, business logic, semantics,associations, schemas and APIs.
üèóÔ∏è CreationDelivered by SAP for SAP LoB ApplicationsBuilt by customers from any SAP/non-SAP data sources
üîÑ UpdatesAutomatically updated by SAP (versioning)Updates controlled by the customer
üß≠ GovernanceFully governed and aligned with SAP standardsGovernance defined by customer policies
üîó ConnectivityReady-to-use with SAP source systems via BDC FormationsUsing SAP Datasphere Native Integrations, SAP BW Data Product Generator 
üóÇÔ∏è Storage LayerSAP BDC FOS (Foundational Service) Layer i.e. HANA Data Lake Files (HDLFs)SAP Datasphere Object Store i.e HANA Data Lake Files (HDLFs)
üîç DiscoverabilityPublished by SAP in Business Accelerator Hub or SAP BDC catalogCustomer need to list and publish it to the catalog.
‚öôÔ∏è Use Cases
  • Best for standard analytics, planning, AI across SAP solutions like SAP S/HANA Cloud (Private/Public), SuccessFactors, Concur, Ariba etc.
  • Ready to consume SAP business application data
  • Intelligent Applications are built upon.
  • Custom analytics (non SAP Data)
  • SAP S/4HANA On-premise, ECC, Non-SAP data sources
  • SAP BW Data Product Generator
  • Unique business logic
  • Extension of Intelligent Applications
  • Local regulations, etc.

 

üì¶What is a Data Package?

Data products are grouped into Data Packages for easier discovery, deployment, and management. A data package may span multiple business domains, such as:  Billing Document,Sales Order, Sales Quotation etc.  This packaging enables users to activate, install and use related data products collectively.

e.g.: Data Package: SAP Sales Data Products (SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition), contains multiple data products like Billing Document,Customer Return,Sales Order, Sales Quotation etc. Each data product can be build upon multiple entities e.g. 
Sales Order data product is based on the CDS entities Sales Order(I_SalesOrder) and Sales Order Item(I_SalesOrderItem).

 Where to find more details about SAP Data Products?

Navigate to Business Accelerator Hub -> Data Products -> Select the Product
 
 
Goto API reference for the source API or entities details.

High-level Workflow for the SAP Managed Data Product Activation:

Why use Data Products instead of direct tables for master or transaction raw data?

Unlike raw database tables that are often fragmented, inconsistent, and require heavy lifting for transformation and understanding, Data Products in SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) provide a ready-to-use, governed, and semantically rich abstraction of the data. These are:

  • Curated and harmonized: Built from SAP S/4HANA and other sources with standardized definitions and business rules.
  • Read-only and analytics-optimized: Designed for high-performance analytical workloads without risk of accidental changes.
  • Easily discoverable via the Data Product Directory and consumable through APIs.
  • Trustworthy: Certified with clear data lineage, ensuring users can rely on them across applications.
  • Reusable and composable: Multiple data products can be combined to build complex models, accelerating time to insights.
  • Enable self-service: Business users can access and explore data without deep technical knowledge, reducing dependency on IT.

By using Data Products, organizations achieve better data consistency, governance, faster decision-making, and agility, which is difficult to achieve with just raw tables.

Why must Data Products be stored on the Object Store (HDLFS) in SAP Business Data Cloud?

Data Products are stored in the object store (HDLFS) to support modern, scalable, and cost-efficient analytics use cases, particularly when dealing with high data volumes. Here's why:

  • Delta Table & Zero-Copy Share Support: Object store enables the use of Delta tables and the Delta Sharing protocol ‚Äî a powerful, open-source mechanism that allows data sharing without copying or moving the data.
  • Efficient Storage via Data Lake: Unlike operational databases like SAP HANA (used for transactional workloads), a data lake is used in analytical environments to reduce storage costs. SAP Business Data Cloud leverages the SAP HANA Cloud Data Lake to store data as efficient files, not traditional tables.
  • Broader Tool Compatibility: File-based storage enables wider integration with various analytical and consumption tools, enhancing flexibility for downstream applications.
  • Scalable and Governed Sharing: With Delta Sharing, Data Products are exposed in a governed, scalable, and open manner, allowing users across the organization to securely consume up-to-date data ‚Äî without duplication or manual transfers.

In short, storing Data Products on the object store ensures low-cost, high-scale, interoperable, and secure data sharing and analytics.

You can learn more about Delta Sharing here: https://delta.io

How to Consume and Activate SAP Managed Data Products ?

  • Activate Data Package.
  • Install Intelligent Application.
  • Provisioning of Business Data Cloud: Installation of Intelligent Applications and Data Packages

 

Summary:

In SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC), data products are curated, self-describing packages of business data that replace raw tables with harmonized, analytics-optimized datasets. SAP does the heavy lifting for customers by providing ready-to-use, SAP-managed data products out of the box for all Line of Business applications. This gives customer a trusted and governed data foundation, making it easy to build everything from BI reports to AI models while leveraging cost-effective, scalable storage for high-volume analytics. Happy Learning üôÇ!

Further Resources or References:

  • https://help.sap.com/docs/business-data-cloud 
  • https://pages.community.sap.com/topics/business-data-cloud

entry.title: SAP Business Data Cloud Series ‚Äì Part 2: Extend SAP S/4HANA Managed Data Products
entry.content:
Introduction:

In Part 1(SAP Business Data Cloud Series ‚Äì Part 1: Introduction to Data Products) of this blog series, we explored the fundamentals of Data Products in SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC). Now, in Part 2, we dive into the practical aspect of extending SAP-managed Data Products, specifically, how to incorporate custom Y/Z fields into the standard SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud Managed Data Products. If you have already enhanced the underlying CDS views or entities in your SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud Edition (PCE) system before activating the corresponding data package or installing the intelligent application, the good news is that your custom fields will automatically flow into the Data Product upon activation. No additional steps required!

In this article, we‚Äôll walk through a common extension scenario involving Sales Order and Billing/Invoice CDS views or SAP Data Products:

 

Data ProductData Source CDS
Sales OrderI_SalesOrder
Sales Order ItemI_SalesOrderItem
Billing Document ItemI_BillingDocumentItemDEX
 

Steps to Extend SAP S/4HANA Managed Data Products Using Key User Extensibility

1. Set Up Adaptation Transport Organizer (ATO): As a prerequisite, ensure ATO is configured to support key user extensions in your system.

2. Add Custom Fields via SAP Fiori App: Open the Custom Fields and Logic app in SAP Fiori and create the required Y/Z custom fields.

How to find business context? Use Tcode: SCFD_REGISTRY

Select Business Context for SD_SALESDOC for Sales Document (Order) and SD_SALESDOCITEM for Sales Document Item.

Similarly  select Business Context SD_BILLINGDOCITEM for Billing Document Item 

Fill the custom field technical details like label, id, data type etc.

3. Publish Custom Fields:After creating the fields, publish them. This step will automatically append your custom fields to the underlying SAP standard ABAP tables.

Publish the field, below one is shown for CampaignID which is added to billing document item.

Likewise it can be done for Sales order (ZZ1_Custom1) and Sales order item (ZZ1_Custom2) custom fields extension.

After above steps custom fields should be appended to standard ABAP tables: VBAK, VBAP and VBRP in our scenario.

VBAK:

 VBAP:

VBRP:

4. Extend the CDS Views or Entities :Enhance the relevant CDS views/entities to include the newly created custom fields.
If the CDS view is listed in the Extensibility Registry (T-code: SCFD_REGISTRY), use Data Source Extensions, this is the recommended approach before resorting to manual CDS view or entity extensions, as demonstrated below.
Alright, we will use CDS extension to include the added and published custom fields:

4.1: Extend CDS View I_SalesOrder to include ZZ_CUSTOM1 field. You can also view the data definitions which got created, when custom fields where published using the Fiori App Custom Fields and Logic.

@AbapCatalog.sqlViewAppendName:  'ZEXTSALESORDER'
@EndUserText.label: 'Extension View for I_SalesOrder'
extend view I_SalesOrder with ZEXTEND_SALESORDER
{
ZZ1_Custom1_SDH as ZZ_CUSTOM1
}

Once extension view is activated, you can now test the CDS extractor/view (SE16N):

4.2: Extend CDS View I_SalesOrderItem to include ZZ1_CUSTOM2 field. You can also view in the Eclipse ADT perspective, what CDS extensions have been created for the CDS view, click on the spiral icon.

@AbapCatalog.sqlViewAppendName:  'ZEXTSALESORDITEM'
@EndUserText.label: 'Extension View for I_SalesOrderItem'
extend view I_SalesOrderItem with ZEXTEND_SALESORDERITEM
{
ZZ1_Custom2_SDI as ZZ1_Custom2
}

Click on spiral icon:

4.3: Extend CDS Entity I_BillingDocumentItemDEX to include ZZ_CampaignID field. 
Note: In previous scenarios, we extended CDS views; in this case, we are extending a CDS entity. CDS entity does not have SQL view created.

extend view entity I_BillingDocumentItemDEX with
{
  _Extension.ZZ1_CampaignID_BDI as ZZ_CampaignID

}

5. Validate Data in CDS Views/Entities: Test the extended CDS views to confirm that the custom fields are populated with data (assuming relevant business logic is in place and transactional data has been updated). e.g. For Sales Order extension use released BAdIs enhancement spot ES_SD_SLS_EXTEND, classic ABAP has user-exit MV45AFZZ (this is out of scope for this blog).

In previous using SE16N we validated that fields are populated on the extended views or entities. 

6. Activate the Data Package in the SAP BDC Cockpit :Proceed to activate the related data package that uses the extended CDS views and has data products of interest.
Note: SAP-managed Data products cannot be activated individually. They only can be activated via Intelligent Application or on data package level. That means that all the data products within the data package or Intelligent Application are activated in one step.

Data Package: SAP Sales Data Products( SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition) has the Data Products 1.Sales Order and 2. Billing Documet.

Once you activate the data package, on the SAP S/4HANA side you can check in the Tcode DHADM for subscription, data replication etc.

Transfer jobs overview:

 

APRS is pushing to target HANA Data Lake Files i.e. SAP BDC Foundational services (FOS) layer.

Target HDLF file path:

Give some time based on the data volume of the data products for the data package to become active. 

7. Install the Data Product: Install the SAP-managed data product corresponding to the activated data package.
Currently, Delta-Share or zero-copy works only with Databricks. In SAP Datasphere, these data products are replicated from the FOS layer into the SAP Datasphere Ingestion Space (SAP managed). In the future, SAP Datasphere will also support Delta-Share.

Prerequisite step:  Add space WS_IT so that you can install the data product (via sharing from the system ingestion space).

Next, we will install data products into the SAP Datasphere WS_IT Space (User Modeling Space).
This process creates a data product share from the SAP-managed Ingestion Space to the user-managed WS_IT Space in our scenario.

Go to SAP Datasphere ‚Üí Catalog & Marketplace.

Data Access Type:

Remote Tables: By default, data is only federated (delta-share) from from FOS layer into SAP Datasphere Ingestion space. . Output: Remote table.

 Replication flow to Local Tables: data is replicated from from FOS layer into SAP Datasphere Ingestion space. Output: Local table(delta-enabled) and Replication flow.

Choose the required option as per the business requirement, as data federation may degrade performance. 

Now, we have successfully installed the Data Products.

8. Preview Data in Local Table: Finally, preview the data within the Data Product‚Äôs local table to confirm that the custom fields are available and populated with the data.
We can view in the WS_IT space, all the data products are installed (shared).

If we click on Billing Document Item data product, then it will navigate to SAP managed Datasphere Ingestion Space RI4400(SAP-Managed).

Great, the data products, now enhanced with your custom (Z) fields, have been successfully installed and are ready for to be used in Datasphere modeling or delta-share with Databricks.

Q: We need to extend an already installed data product. How should we handle this situation?

A: Currently, when you need to extend or change an existing data product, the process On the SAP S/4HANA source side, any changes you make will be handled within the existing framework. On the SAP BDC side, however, you must either deactivate the entire data package or uninstall the intelligent application and then activate or reinstall it to incorporate the new changes to the data product. It is not the most efficient way to handle a small change of adding new field to the data product. The product team is aware of this and is working on a solution to provide more granular control at the data product level, which would allow for more targeted updates in the future.

Summary:

In this blog, we saw how to extend SAP S/4HANA Managed Data Products by adding custom fields and making them available in SAP Business Data Cloud, SAP Datasphere. We learned how to use the Custom Fields and Logic app, extend CDS entities, and replicate the updated data by data product activation. Things are improving and getting rapidly in the product, and I will do my best to keep this blog updated with the latest changes. Happy Learning üôÇ!

entry.title: Implementing Data Flows in SAP Datasphere: Concepts and Examples
entry.content:
Understanding Data Flows in SAP Datasphere

Introduction

In SAP Datasphere, flows are a key component for implementing ETL (Extract, Transform, Load) and ELT (Extract, Load, Transform) processes. We can think of Data flow as traditional ETL pipelines whereas Replication flow aligns more closely with modern data engineering practices where raw data is replicated or ingested into the data lakes and then transformation logic is applied afterwards which aligns with transformation flow. Below are the three types of flows available.

  1. Data Flow
  2. Replication Flow
  3. Transformation Flow

In this blog post, we‚Äôll focus on the end to end functionalities in Data Flow ‚Äî covering the below areas.

  1. What is Data Flow?
  2. Why Use a Data Flow?
  3. Data flow Comparison with Replication and Transformation flows.
  4. Data load modes for target tables.
  5. How to create a Data Flow?
  6. How to use Custom Python script in Data Flow?
  7. How to use input parameters in Data Flow?
  8. How to schedule the Data Flow?

What Is a Data Flow in SAP Datasphere?

A Data Flow in SAP Datasphere is used to integrate and transform data from both SAP and non-SAP sources, and move it between various targets within the Datasphere environment.

It supports:

- Standard transformation operations: filter, join, union, aggregation

- Advanced operations using Python scripts

- Batch processing workloads

It‚Äôs comparable to SAP BODS or Process Chains in SAP BW.

Source Compatibility:

Data Flows are supported for most sources currently integrated with Datasphere, including:

- SAP S/4HANA CDS views

- SLT (SAP Landscape Transformation)

- Non-SAP sources like Amazon Redshift, Google BigQuery, and Azure Data Lake

However, they do not support:

- ODP-based data sources (e.g., classic BW extractors)

- SAP BW/4HANA 

- Amazon Athena

For delta extraction from S/4HANA, you must use delta-enabled CDS views.

Why Use a Data Flow?

- To bring data into SAP Datasphere from various sources

- To perform complex transformations (e.g., business logic, calculations)

- To persist intermediate or final datasets within different layers (e.g., raw, harmonized, consumption)

Data Flow vs Replication Flow vs Transformation Flow

Here is a quick comparison between 3 flows based on their use cases.

Flow Type

Primary Use Case

Transformation

Notes

Data Flow

ETL

Yes

Transform and load

Replication Flow

ELT

No

Just extracts and loads

Transformation Flow

Post-load transforms

Yes

Works on already loaded data

Data Load Modes for Target Tables

When loading data to a target table in a Data Flow, you can choose from three update modes:

 

1. Append

- Inserts all incoming records as new rows

- Does not affect existing data

- Use Case: Incremental/historical loads

2. Truncate

- Deletes all existing records from the table before loading new data

- Use Case: Full refresh scenarios

3. Delete

- Deletes only records in the target that match incoming records (based on keys/conditions)

- Use Case: Targeted clean-up before loading updated records.

How to Create a Data Flow

Example: Persist Sales Transactions by combining them with Product and Store details.

Steps:

1. Go to Data Builder ‚Üí Select Flows.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

2.Click New Data Flow

 

3. In the canvas:

    - From the HANA_CLOUD connection ‚Üí navigate to the TECHED folder

    - Drag and drop Sales_Transactions123, Product, and Stores tables

 

4. Perform the joins:

    - Join Sales_Transactions with Stores on Store_ID

    - Join Sales_Transactions with Product on Product_ID

       4a.  Add the target table:

    - Click the output node ‚Üí give a name

    - Choose ‚ÄúCreate and Deploy Table‚Äù

5. Save and Deploy the data flow

6. Click Run to execute the flow

 

7. We can use the schedule option to run it on predefined intervals and monitor the execution using Data Integration Monitor or Data Flow Monitor.

Custom Python Step in a Data Flow

For simple filters and aggregation we can use the filter and calculated columns functionalities available graphically. For more advanced complex data transformations involving conditional logic, string parsing, KPI buckets we can make use of script operator. 

Let‚Äôs embed a Simple Python script inside the above Data Flow to calculate few KPI‚Äôs.

Steps:

1. I have copied the above data flow and created a new one with script operator. Insert the script operator after J_PRODUCT node.

     

2. Edit the Script Node and paste the below code:

Note: We need not use import pandas in Datasphere. It's already available internally.

def transform(data):

    df = data.copy()

 

    epsilon = 1e-9

 

    df['profit_margin'] = df['Profit'] / (df['Revenue'] + epsilon) * 100

    df['discount_rate'] = df['Discount'] / (df['Revenue'] + epsilon) * 100

    df['cost_to_revenue'] = df['Cost'] / (df['Revenue'] + epsilon) * 100

 

    df['high_discount_flag'] = df['discount_rate'] > 20

 

    df['profit_category'] = df['profit_margin'].apply(

        lambda x: 'High' if x > 30 else ('Medium' if x > 10 else 'Low')

    )

    return df

```

3. Create new columns for all the above calculated values. 

4. Add the target table. Create and deploy the table.

5. Save and deploy the data flow.

6. Execute the flow ‚Äî you‚Äôll see the KPI‚Äôs populated in the output.

Input Parameters in Data Flow

We can create input parameters to dynamically populate the values entered by the user which can be used in filters and calculated columns.

1. Click on blank space in the canvas editor and click on input parameters from the details pane.

2. Create a new input parameter IP_STORE_ID with type string.

 

3. I have inserted a projection node between the J_PRODUCT node and script node. We can create filters, calculated columns in projection node. I have defined the below filter condition that uses the input parameter we just created. 

 

4. Save and deploy the data flow.  Once you run the dataflow it will prompt to enter the input parameter.

 

5. It‚Äôs running with ST9 as store ID.

 

Schedule

Schedule is used to run the dataflow on a recurrent basis similar to process chain batch loads. To run recurring scheduled tasks on your behalf, we need to authorize the job scheduling component.We can also authorize from your profile settings page.

1. Click on Create from Schedule drop down option. Click on Authorize.

 

 

2. I have scheduled it to run at 12.30 PM UTC.

 3.  In the Data integration monitor we can see it is scheduled to run every day.

Conclusion

This blog introduced the Data Flow feature in SAP Datasphere, highlights how it differs from other flow types, and explains key concepts such as update modes. It also walks through both standard and Python-based examples, covering input parameters and scheduling options.

entry.title: Difference between Replication flow vs Remote Table replication flow in Datasphere
entry.content:
Hi,

This content will help us to understand the major difference between Replication flow & Remote Table - Replication flow in one page 

What connectors require ?

Replication flow : SAP Cloud connector can be used to connect ABAP Based systems  

Remote Table Replication flow : DP Agent acts as bridge between Dataspehre and On premise system 

Supportable source objects :

Replication flow : Allows the replication of multiple Assests (CDS Views as source) with in single flow. 

Remote Table Replication flow : Individual data asset( CDS View / Table)  

 Data Target : 

Replication flow : Data can load into  both SAP Datasphere and External source systems as target systems 

Remote Replication flow : Target is only SAP Datasphere 

 Data Loads :

 

Replication Flow we have two Options : 

Initial Only : Loads all the data once from the source  

Initial And Delta : After the Initial load System checks for source data changes at regular intervals and transfer delta to the target system  

We can customize the interval you can customize this interval via the side panel, setting it to any value between 0-24 hours and 0-59 minutes 

 

Remote Table Replication : We have two Modes  

Snapshot replication: This method copies the full dataset from a source object (e.g., a database table of view) into SAP Datasphere in one go (ie. a static full load per run) Ex month end balances , Head counts 

Real-Time Data Replication via ‚ÄúEnable Real-Time Data Replication‚Äù option Here, data changes from the source object are continuously replicated into SAP Datasphere, until the run is terminated manually/per schedule. replication frequency is system-defined and cannot be manually adjusted in SAP Datasphere  

What is Partitioning and Parallelization 

Partitioning and parallelizing the data transfers improves performance when replicating large datasets. 

The approach varies depending on the source object type 

ABAP source system, SLT-table, and CDS-view based data replication: Partitions are calculated automatically, but users can manually adjust them via SAP ABAP system parameters 

ABAP source system, ODP based data replication: By default, the number of partitions is 3. But users can modify this via the ODP_RMS_PARTITIONS_LOAD parameter in SAP ABAP system. 

Database source system, table-based replication: Partitions are automatically determined and cannot be modified. 

Parllel processing :  

A replication flow can contain a maximum of 500 replication objects. 

By default, a replication flow can utilize up to two replication flow jobs 

A replication flow job can process up to five work orders for data transfer and five work orders for housekeeping. (Work orders are internal objects that are needed to organize the work efficiently.)  

If a replication object is divided into partitions, each partition is processed by one work order. 

Each data transfer work order requires a thread, that is, a technical connection to both the source and target 

Each replication flow counts towards the total possible maximum of 10 parallel jobs in one tenant. 

if you have 10 replication flow jobs, you can process a total possible maximum of 50 work orders for data transfer and 50 work orders for housekeeping. With one thread per work order, the total maximum for threads is 100 for the source and for the target, respectively. (You can still have more than 10 replication flows, but not more than 10 replication flows can run in parallel at any given point in time.) 

Sizing for Delta Loading 

For delta loading, the default is that each object is processed as one partition by one data transfer work order, resulting in a total of 5 data transfer work orders and one replication flow job being utilized 

The main intention of this blog is to clarify in which scenario we opt replication flow and  Remote table replication flow. Utilization of them is different though they are identical in nature.

You can Add your thoughts or knowledge which i missed to list here 

Best Regards,

Kartheek Kota

entry.title: SAP Datasphere Automation : Creating Database user in SAP Datasphere using Datasphere CLI & Python
entry.content:
Introduction

One way to access datasphere hana database is via database users. Each database user is linked to one space (except database analysis user). We can create database user vai GUI however, its a long process and prone to errors. In this blog, i will share my work on how i automated the process using SAP Datasphere CLI and Python without the need to login into datasphere GUI.

Old Process:

If you want to create a database user via GUI, you need to perform the below steps.

  1. Login into the datasphere tenant. Make sure you have the required application roles to perform the task.
  2. Go to Space management and select the space. Scroll down and click create in database user. 
  3. Provide the username and deploy the space. Save the password and share it with the user. 

Automated Process

To overcome the long process, i have divided the python script to perform all these task in sequential manner. 

  1. Datasphere CLI Setup : Set the CLI and login into datasphere
  2. Reading the metadata: Read the space metadata using SAP Datasphere CLI space read command
  3. Modifying JSON : Enhance the output JSON with the new user details and deploy it using the space create command
  4. Password Reset : Reset the database user password and save it in a file for sharing.

Set up SAP Datasphere CLI (First time only)

To start working with Datasphere CLI, we need to perform few one time configuration like setting host, login in and setting cache. If you want to login via a different tenant, you need to change the CLIENT_ID and CLIENT_SECRETS as per the tenant.

datasphere config set host {"host_url"}
datasphere login --client-id {"client_id"} --client-secret {"client_secret"}
datasphere config set cache --client-id {"client_id"} --client-secret {"client_secret"}

 Once you are done with the initial setup of CLI, we can start working on the main code which will create database users.

Reading space metadata

Since we do not have a direct command to create DB user, we extract the space metadata JSON using CLI. This command output the space metadata JSON into console. I have stored this into a variable that i will use later in modifying the JSON

space_Json = datasphere space read -space "{space"} --definations

Modifying the JSON and deploying it in datasphere 

To create a new databased user in space, we need to add the new user details in the dbuser object of the JSON. We can store the space metadata JSON into our local machine and modify it or we can modify it on the go using tempfiles. I have used the later approach as it eliminates the need of JSON management 

#Concatenating the space and username
new_db_user = f"{space}#{username}"

#Appending the new_db_user details into the space metadata JSON
space_JSON[space]["spaceDefinition"]["dbusers"][new_db_user] = {
"ingestion":{
        "auditing":{
          "dppRead":{
            "retentionPeriod":21
            "isAuditPolicyActive":True
          },
         
        }
      },
      "consumption":{
        "consumptionWithGrant":false,
        "spaceSchemaAccess":True,
        "scriptServerAccess":false,
        "localSchemaAccess":false,
        "hdiGrantorForCupsAccess":false
}

Once the JSON is modified, write the new JSON into a temporary file. I have stored the file path into a variable called tmp_file_path. I will push this file path to datasphere tenant.

#Pushing the modified JSON to datasphere tenant
datasphere space create --file-path "{tmp_file_path}" -- force-defination-deployment

If you want to delete a database user, remove the entry from the JSON and run the same command and add --enforce-database-user-deletion in the end. If this command is not added, then the deletion will not work.

Password Reset

Once the database user is created, we need to reset the password to store it in a local file for sharing. Below is the command to perform that action

datasphere dbusers password reset --space{"space"} --databaseuser {"new_db_user"}

 (Tip: Add a 30 seconds wait time between creating the database user and resetting the password commands because the space deployment takes some time and we cannot reset the password before that).

I have also added an automatic email creation in my workflow and inserting database user details into a local table for future analysis.

Conclusion:

With this automation, we can create database users in datasphere tenant without even login into datasphere. This workflow provides a more robust way to handle creation and maintenance database users. 

I would love to know your thoughts on this workflow in the comments below. Lets explore more opportunities of automation using datasphere CLI.

entry.title: Optimizing Data Movement in SAP Datasphere: Replication Flow or Remote Table Replication?
entry.content:
Choosing the Right Data Replication Strategy in SAP Datasphere: Replication Flow or Remote Table Replication?

When moving data into SAP Datasphere, you‚Äôll often choose between Replication Flow and Remote Table Replication.

On the surface, they seem similar, but their operational behavior, use cases, and system impact differ significantly.

This blog uses a scenario-driven approach to help you decide which option is best for your needs. We'll also cover recent updates, such as the Delta Only mode for Replication Flows and Create Statistics for Remote Tables.

 

1. How Do They Connect to Your Source Systems?

  • Replication Flow leverages the SAP Cloud Connector to establish a secure tunnel for connecting to on-premise ABAP-based systems. 

  • Remote Table Replication uses the Data Provisioning (DP) Agent to create a bridge between SAP Datasphere and various on-premise data sources.

2. How Many Objects Can You Move at Once?

  • Replication Flow can move multiple objects (e.g., several CDS Views) within a single flow.

  • Remote Table Replication is limited to one object (a single table or CDS View) per replication process.

3. Where Does the Data Go?

  • Replication Flow ‚Äì SAP Datasphere or external targets.

  • Remote Table Replication ‚Äì SAP Datasphere only.

4. How Often Does Data Get Loaded?

Replication Flow supports:

  • Initial Only ‚Äì One-time full load.

  • Delta Only ‚Äì Load only changes from the source without performing an initial load.

  • Initial + Delta ‚Äì Full load followed by scheduled delta updates (intervals configurable).

Remote Table Replication supports:

  • No Replication ‚Äì Query data live from the source.

  • Snapshot ‚Äì One-time static copy.

  • Real-Time ‚Äì Provides continuous updates. For database sources, this is achieved using database triggers, and the update frequency is system-defined.

5. Additional Capability: Create Statistics for Remote Tables

A recent enhancement allows you to create statistics for Remote Tables to better understand your dataset and optimize queries.

When selecting Create Statistics on a Remote Table, you can choose:

  1. Record Count ‚Äì Returns the total number of rows in the table.

  2. Simple ‚Äì Provides column-level metrics such as min, max, null count, total count, and distinct count.

  3. Histogram ‚Äì Displays data distribution per column for more advanced performance tuning and analytics.

This feature is useful for both performance optimization and ensuring data quality in replicated or live-query scenarios.

6. How Do They Handle Large Data Volumes?

Partitioning improves performance for big datasets:

  • Replication Flow (SLT/CDS as Source) ‚Äì Automatic partitioning, adjustable via ABAP parameters.

  • Replication Flow (ODP as Source) ‚Äì Defaults to 3 partitions; can be adjusted using ODP_RMS_PARTITIONS_LOAD.

  • Database sources ‚Äì Automatic and fixed.

Parallelization limits:

  • Objects per flow: A maximum of 500 replication objects can be added to a single Replication Flow.

  • Jobs per flow: By default, each Replication Flow can utilize up to 2 jobs.

  • Jobs per tenant: A maximum of 10 parallel jobs can run per SAP Datasphere tenant.

7. Technical Footprint on the Source System

  • Replication Flow ‚Äì Creates subscribers in the source system.

  • Remote Table Real-Time Replication ‚Äì uses database triggers. Be aware that these triggers must be removed before transports to avoid RC8 errors.

8. Decision Guide: Which Should You Choose?

Scenario Best Choice

Load multiple objects in one job

Replication Flow

Need flexible scheduling

Replication Flow

Real-time sync for a single object

Remote Table Replication

Must avoid triggers in the source

Replication Flow

Send data to external targets

Replication Flow

Limit storage in SAP Datasphere

Remote Table (No Replication)

Already have initial data and need only changes

Replication Flow (Delta Only)

9. Takeaway

Think of Replication Flow as a customizable cargo service ‚Äî you decide how many shipments to send, how often, and even whether they‚Äôre full loads or just the latest updates. It‚Äôs flexible, scalable, and works well when you have multiple packages (objects) to move.

Remote Table Replication, on the other hand, is more like direct live access or a dedicated delivery route ‚Äî it specializes in one shipment at a time and can either keep it live or make an exact copy for you to work with.

By understanding the connectivity, load modes, and operational footprint of each method, you can choose the one that not only delivers your data but also aligns perfectly with your project's performance and governance needs.

entry.title: What is the minimum capacity units (CU) to activate Object Store in SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC)?
entry.content:
Symptom: You are unsure of the number of capacity units (CU) required to activate Object Store in Business Data Cloud (BDC). 

Requirements: N/A.

Resolution: The minimum capacity units required to activate Object Store in BDC is 4150.05 CU (128 GB of SAP HANA memory). You can simulate this number in SAP Business Data Cloud Capacity Unit Estimator. 

1) Open SAP Business Data Cloud Capacity Unit Estimator

2) Select your Hyperscaler and Data Center

3) Click "Add" and double-click "SAP Datasphere"

4) Increase memory in "Compute" card until we have 128 GB

5) Add 1 block (minimum) in "Object Store Storage" card to activate this feature

6) Adjust parameters according to your needs in the simulator

7) View the final CU estimator for your business case
